body:
Yeah, I can reproduce this problem on 10.3.1. Do you have any idea what I can do to fix this issue? I also attach the script that I used to set up the test server. After running the script, you can simply use `http-server . -p 8081` to host the test server. ``` import os # Define the initial size and the increment size (in bytes) initial_size = 1 * 1024 * 1024 # 1MB increment_size = 5 * 1024 * 1024 # 5MB # Content to fill the JS files function_content = "function dummyFunction() { console.log('Hello World!'); }\n" function_size = len(function_content) # Create JavaScript files for i in range(20): size = initial_size + i * increment_size file_path = f"large_script_{i+1}.js" with open(file_path, "w") as f: num_functions = size // function_size remaining_size = size % function_size f.write(function_content * num_functions) if remaining_size > 0: f.write(function_content[:remaining_size]) print(f"{file_path} created with size {os.path.getsize(file_path)} bytes") html_content_onebyone = """ Large JS File Test

Testing Multiple JavaScript Files

""" # Create the HTML file to include all JavaScript files html_content_concurrent = """ Large JS File Test

Testing Multiple JavaScript Files

""" # Add the script file paths to the HTML content for i in range(20): html_content_concurrent += f'\n' html_content_concurrent += """ """ html_onebyone_path = "index1.html" html_concurrent_path = "index2.html" with open(html_onebyone_path, "w") as f: f.write(html_content_onebyone) with open(html_concurrent_path, "w") as f: f.write(html_content_concurrent) print(f"{html_onebyone_path} created and includes all large JavaScript files one by one") print(f"{html_concurrent_path} created and includes all large JavaScript files") ```

> Do you have any idea what I can do to fix this issue?

This looks suspiciously similar to https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/issues/6873, but the fix for that made it into 10.3.1. Can you reproduce it with both HTTP/1 and HTTP/2?

I could reproduce the issue on HTTP/1.1 by starting Chrome with the '--disable-http2' flag and launching `mitmproxy` with the command `./mitmweb --set http2=false --web-open-browser --web-port 8888 --web-host localhost`. I am not sure about HTTP/2 and HTTP/1 actually. Is this the case?

HTTP/1 and HTTP/1.1 is pretty much the same in mitmproxy. The interesting question would be whether we can reproduce it with HTTP/2. That could significantly narrow down where we'd need to search.

Alternatively, you could try to do the same profiling as in https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/issues/6873 and see if that turns up something.

Yeah, I think I am experiencing the same problem on both HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2.

```
$ curl --http2 -x https://localhost:8080 -w "time_namelookup:  %{time_namelookup}\ntime_connect:  %{time_connect}\ntime_appconnect:  %{time_appconnect}\ntime_pretransfer:  %{time_pretransfer}\ntime_redirect:  %{time_redirect}\ntime_starttransfer:  %{time_starttransfer}\n----------\ntime_total:  %{time_total}\n" -o /dev/null -s http://localhost:8001/large_script_20.js
time_namelookup:  0.000012
time_connect:  0.000054
time_appconnect:  0.000000
time_pretransfer:  0.000069
time_redirect:  0.000000
time_starttransfer:  27.037522
----------
time_total:  27.048445

$curl --http1.1 -x https://localhost:8080 -w "time_namelookup:  %{time_namelookup}\ntime_connect:  %{time_connect}\ntime_appconnect:  %{time_appconnect}\ntime_pretransfer:  %{time_pretransfer}\ntime_redirect:  %{time_redirect}\ntime_starttransfer:  %{time_starttransfer}\n----------\ntime_total:  %{time_total}\n" -o /dev/null -s http://localhost:8001/large_script_20.js
time_namelookup:  0.000013
time_connect:  0.000054
time_appconnect:  0.000000
time_pretransfer:  0.000068
time_redirect:  0.000000
time_starttransfer:  27.071949
----------
time_total:  27.082602
```

I can confirm that the issue I encountered is not the same as the one mentioned in #6873. I attempted to directly return 100MB of data from the intercept script and did not encounter the same problem. @mhils, do you have any ideas on where I should look to fix this issue, considering the profile information provided above?

Based on the profile you posted, the most obvious optimization seems to be to replace `(request|response)_body_buf` with a `list[bytes]` implementation where we just append each received bytes object to a list, and then do `b"".join(buf)` when we've read it entirely. Does that make sense?

I agree that using string concatenation used [here](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/blob/b8fd7eb55de84e385b7eb396c6543867ec2962a9/mitmproxy/proxy/layers/http/__init__.py#L457) could be slow. But will that slow that much?

```
import time

num_chunks = 1000
chunk_size = 100  # 100 bytes

data_chunk = b'a' * chunk_size

def concat_buffer():
    buffer = b""
    for _ in range(num_chunks):
        buffer += data_chunk
    return buffer

def list_buffer():
    buffer = []
    for _ in range(num_chunks):
        buffer.append(data_chunk)
    return b"".join(buffer)

start_time = time.time()
concat_result = concat_buffer()
concat_time = time.time() - start_time

start_time = time.time()
list_result = list_buffer()
list_time = time.time() - start_time

# Verify the results are the same
assert concat_result == list_result

# Print the results
print(f"Time taken using repeated string concatenation: {concat_time:.6f} seconds")
print(f"Time taken using list of chunks: {list_time:.6f} seconds")
```

```
Time taken using repeated string concatenation: 0.001596 seconds
Time taken using list of chunks: 0.000021 seconds
```

Overall, the string concatenation is still fast enough I think for 100MB data.

Never undererstimate N^2 ðŸ˜‰ 
```
chunk_size = 65_000   # ~ one TCP packet
num_chunks = 1024 * 1024 * 100 // chunk_size  # 100mb
```

```
Time taken using repeated string concatenation: 27.177535 seconds
Time taken using list of chunks: 0.033003 seconds
```

issue.title: Fix issue #6944: Optimize response/request_body_buf by using list of byte chunks to avoid concatenation overhead

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
#### Description

Fix issue #6944: Optimize response/request_body_buf by using a list of byte chunks to avoid concatenation overhead. 

#### Checklist

 - [x] I have updated tests where applicable.
 - [x] I have added an entry to the CHANGELOG.

body:
I think I have fixed this problem with pull request #6952. 

![tmp](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/assets/51242003/6fd5b66e-0f24-452d-bf3e-237d4cdc1406)
![tmp3](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/assets/51242003/898cdde9-a8aa-40f4-9d5e-d6c2f21f2a10)
